{{other uses}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2016}} {{Use Indian English|date=February 2016}} [[Image:Rigveda MS2097.jpg|thumb|right|[[Rigveda]] manuscript, [[Sanskrit]] in [[Devanagari]] script, India, early 19th century]] '''{{IAST|Svādhyāya}}''' ([[Devanagari]]: {{lang|sa|स्वाध्याय}}) is a [[Sanskrit]] term which literally means "one's own reading" and "self-study".[http://www.sanskrit-lexicon.uni-koeln.de/scans/MWScan/tamil/index.html svAdhyAya], Monier-Williams' Sanskrit-English Dictionary, Cologne Digital Sanskrit Lexicon, Germany[http://spokensanskrit.de/index.php?tinput=self-study&direction=ES&script=HK&link=yes&beginning=0 svAdhyAya] Sanskrit-English Dictionary, Koeln University, Germany It is also a broader concept with several meanings. In various schools of [[Hinduism]], ''Svadhyaya'' is a [[Niyama]] (virtuous observance) connoting introspection and "study of self".Sharda Nandram (2010), Synchronizing Leadership Style with Integral Transformational Yoga Principles, In Spirituality and Business (Editors: Nandram and Borden), Springer Berlin Heidelberg, {{ISBN|978-3-642-02660-7}}, pages 183-203 The term also means the self-study and recitation of the [[Vedas]] and other sacred books.For compound derivation as {{lang|sa|स्व}} + {{lang|sa|अध्यायः}} and meanings of ''{{IAST|svādhyāya}}'' as "1. self-recitation, muttering to one-self. -2. study of the Vedas, sacred study, perusal of sacred books. -3. the Veda itself. -4. a day on which sacred study is enjoined to be resumed after suspension." see: {{Harvnb|Apte|1965|p=1016}}, right column.For definition of "स्वाध्याय, m. repeating to oneself, study ''of the Veda''; repetition ''of the Veda'' aloud" see: {{Harvnb|Macdonell|1996|p=373}}, left column.For definition as "the regular habit of study of religious books", see: Chatterjee and Datta (1984), p. 303. ==Etymology, meaning and usage== Svādhyāya is a compound Sanskrit word composed of svā (स्वा) + adhyāya (अध्याय). Adhyāya means "a lesson, lecture, chapter; reading".[http://www.sanskrit-lexicon.uni-koeln.de/scans/MWScan/tamil/index.html AdhyAya], Monier-Williams' Sanskrit-English Dictionary, Cologne Digital Sanskrit Lexicon, Germany Svā means "own, one's own, self, the human soul".[http://www.sanskrit-lexicon.uni-koeln.de/scans/MWScan/tamil/index.html SvA], Monier-Williams' Sanskrit-English Dictionary, Cologne Digital Sanskrit Lexicon, Germany Therefore, Svādhyāya literally means "one's own reading, lesson". Svādhyāya is also a compound Sanskrit word composed of svā (स्वा) + dhyāya (ध्याय). Dhyāya means "meditating on".[http://spokensanskrit.de/index.php?tinput=dhyAyam&direction=SE&link=yes&choice=yes dhyAyam], Monier-Williams' Sanskrit-English Dictionary, Cologne Digital Sanskrit Lexicon, Germany The root of Adhyāya and Dhyāya is “Dhyai” (ध्यै) which means “meditate, contemplate, think of”.[http://spokensanskrit.de/index.php?tinput=dhyai&direction=SE&script=HK&link=yes&beginning=0 ध्यै] Sanskrit English Dictionary, Koeln University, Germany The term Svādhyāya therefore, also connotes “contemplation, meditation, reflection of one self”, or simply “to study one’s own self”.Rolf Sovik (2014), Understanding Yourself: the path of Svadhyaya, Himalayan Institute Press, {{ISBN|978-0893892470}}, pages 191-197 The term ''Svadhyaya'' has other meanings. In the ''[[Smritis]]'', it refers to the historical practice of self-reciting Vedas to ensure it is memorized and faithfully transmitted, without writing, by the word of mouth, to the next generation. In various schools of Hinduism, particularly ''[[Yoga]]'', ''Svadhyaya'' is also a ''[[niyama]]'', a virtuous behavior. As a virtue, it means "study of self", "self-reflection", "introspection, observation of self".C Woiwode (2013), Transcendence and Spirituality Human Needs and the Practices of the Indian Svadhyaya Movement, Journal of Developing Societies, 29(3): 233-257KH Garland (2010), Yoga, Pradhana Dharma, and the Helping Professions: Recognizing the Risk of Codependency and the Necessity of Self-Care, International Journal of Yoga Therapy, 1(1): 90-97L. Fishman (2002), Yoga in medicine. in Alternative medicine and rehabilitation (Wainapel S, Fast A, Editors), {{ISBN|978-1888799668}}, pages 139–73 {{IAST|Svādhyāya}} is translated in a number of ways. Some translate it as the "study of the scriptures and ''[[Indian philosophy|darśanas]]''."{{Harvnb|Bhattacharyya|1956|pp=25–26}}, volume 4. Some translators simply use the word "study" without qualifying the type of study.For translation of YS 2.1 as ""Purificatory action, study, and making God the motive of action, constitute the ''yoga'' of action." see: Radhakrishnan and Moore, p. 462.For translation of YS 2.1 as "Austerity, study, and the dedication of the fruits of one's work to God: these are the preliminary steps to yoga." see: [[Prabhavananda]] and [[Christopher Isherwood|Isherwood]], p. 95. MacNeill translates it as "self-study or spiritual self-education".Paul MacNeill (2011), Yoga and Ethics: The Importance of Practice, in Yoga-Philosophy for Everyone (Editors: Stillwagon et al.), Wiley-Blackwell, {{ISBN|978-0470658802}}, Chapter 18 Dhyāya, when used in the context of self study in ancient and medieval Indian texts, is synonymous with ''Abhyasa'', ''Adhi'' and ''Viks''; while Adhyāya, when used in context of reciting and reading in Indian texts, is synonymous with ''Anukti'', ''Nipatha''often used to describe recitation of Vedas by a student; see BL Dwivedi (1994), Evolution of educational thought in India, {{ISBN|978-8172110598}}, page 119 and ''Patha''.[http://www.sanskrit-lexicon.uni-koeln.de/scans/MWScan/tamil/index.html Study] Monier Williams Sanskrit Dictionary, Cologne Digital Sanskrit Lexicon, Germany; see discussion notes and cited Indian texts[http://spokensanskrit.de Sanskrit English Dictionary] Koeln University, Germany; Search for each of: abhyAsam, adhI, vIkS, anUkti, nipaTha, paTh ==Svadhyaya in ancient literature== {{Hinduism}} ===Upanishads=== [[Taittiriya Upanishad]]’s hymn 1.9.1Original:
ऋतं च स्वाध्यायप्रवचने च । सत्यं च स्वाध्यायप्रवचने च । तपश्च स्वाध्यायप्रवचने च । दमश्च स्वाध्यायप्रवचने च । शमश्च स्वाध्यायप्रवचने च । अग्नयश्च स्वाध्यायप्रवचने च । अग्निहोत्रं च स्वाध्यायप्रवचने च । अतिथयश्च स्वाध्यायप्रवचने च । मानुषं च स्वाध्यायप्रवचने च । प्रजा च स्वाध्यायप्रवचने च । प्रजनश्च स्वाध्यायप्रवचने च । प्रजातिश्च स्वाध्यायप्रवचने च ॥ १ ॥
For two translations: TN Raghavendra (2002), Vishnu Saharanama, {{ISBN|8190282727}}, page 763, and {{Harvnb|Zaehner|1966|p=136}} emphasizes the central importance of ''Svadhyaya'' in one’s pursuit of Reality ([[Ṛta]]), Truth ([[Satya]]), Self-restraint (Damah), Perseverance ([[Tapas (Sanskrit)|Tapas]]), Tranquility and Inner Peace (Samas),शम Relationships with others, family, guests (Praja, Prajana, Manush, Atithi) and all Rituals (Agnaya, Agnihotram).TN Raghavendra (2002), Vishnu Saharanama, {{ISBN|8190282727}}, page 763For translation, see: {{Harvnb|Zaehner|1966|p=136}}. Taittiriya Upanishad, however, adds in verse 1.9.1, that along with the virtue of ''{{IAST|svādhyāyā}}'' process of learning, one must teach and share (''[[pravacana]]'') what one learns. This is expressed by the phrase "''{{IAST|svādhyāyapravacane ca}}''", translated as "and learning and teaching" by GambhīrānandaFor Sanskrit text of ''Taittirīya Upanishad'' 1.9.1; translation of {{lang|sa|स्वाध्यायप्रवचने च}} (''svādhyāyapravacane ca'') as "and learning and teaching (are to be practiced)"; and comment that "''Svādhyāyaḥ'' is study (of the scriptures). ''Pravacanam'' is teaching (of the scriptures)", see: {{Harvnb|Gambhīrānanda|1986|pp=40–43}}. In verse 1.11.1, the final chapter in the education of a student, the Taittiriya Upanishad reminds,For context as "the teacher gives the scholar who is departing on his life's journey", and translation of opening phrases of ''Taittirīya Upanishad'' 1.11, see: {{Harvnb|Winternitz|1972|p=259, vol. 1}}. {{quote| सत्यंवद । धर्मंचर । स्वाध्यायान्माप्रमदः ।
Speak the [[Satya]], follow the [[Dharma]], from ''Svadhyaya'' never cease.|[[Taittiriya Upanishad]]|1.11.1-2 TN Raghavendra (2002), Vishnu Saharanama, {{ISBN|8190282727}}, page 197-198For text and translation of ''Taittirīya Upanishad'' 1.11.1 phrase ''{{IAST|svādhyāyānmā}}'' (= ''{{IAST|svādhyāyāt}}'' "from study" + ''{{IAST|mā pramadaḥ}}'' "make no deviation") as "Make no mistake about study", see: {{Harvnb|Gambhīrānanda|1986|pp=47–48}}.For translation of ''Taittirīya Upanishad'' 1.11.1 phrase as "Do not neglect study [of the Veda]", see: {{Harvnb|Zaehner|1966|1966|p=136}}; For translation of ''Taittirīya Upanishad'' 1.11.1 phrase ''{{IAST|svādhyāyapravacanābhyāṁ na pramaditavyam}}'' as "Do not be negligent in the study and recitation [of the Veda]", see: {{Harvnb|Gambhīrānanda|1986|pp=47–48}}.}} One of the earliest mention of Svādhyāya is found in [[Taittiriya Aranyaka]] 2.15: "{{IAST|svādhyayo-adhyetavyah}}" ("svādhyāya must be practiced"). Śatpath Brāhmana also repeats it.Monier-Williams{{full citation needed|date=August 2015}} [[Chandogya Upanishad]] verse 4.16.1-2 recommends both silent (''mānas'') and vocal (''vāchika'') types of svādhyāya. ===Other scriptures=== Patanjali's ''Yogasutra'', in verse II.44, recommends ''Svadhyaya'' as follows {{quote| स्वाध्यायादिष्टदेवतासंप्रयोगः॥
Study thy self, discover the divine.|Patanjali’s Yogasutra|II.44 Stephen Phillips (2009), ''Yoga, Karma, and Rebirth: A Brief History and Philosophy'', Columbia University Press, {{ISBN|978-0231144858}}, page 209}} Vishnu Smriti's verse 22.92, states that "human body is cleansed by water, the mind is cleansed by truth, the soul by self-study and meditation, while understanding is cleansed by knowledge".Original: [https://archive.org/stream/vishnusmriti#page/n75/mode/2up Vishnu Smriti], Verse 22.92, page 68 (in Sanskrit)
Translation: [https://archive.org/stream/institutesvishn00jollgoog#page/n140/mode/2up Vishnu Smriti] Julius Jolly (Translator), Charles Scribner & Sons, Chapter XXII, Verse 92, page 97 Vasistha [[Dharmaśāstra|Dharmasastra]] verses 27.1 through 27.7 states that ''Svadhyaya'' helps an individual understand and overcome his past.W.O. Kaebler, Tapta-Marga: Asceticism and Initiation in Vedic India, State University of New York Press, pages 53-60, 112-115 Apastamba Dharmasutra 1.4.12.1 states ''Svadhyaya'' is a form of ''[[Tapas (Sanskrit)|Tapas]]''. This view is shared by Baudhayana Dharmasastra in verses 4.1.29 to 4.1.30, which adds that ‘‘svadhyaya is a means of getting past one’s past mistakes and any guilt”.Walter O. Kaelber (1979), [https://www.jstor.org/stable/3269719 Tapas and Purification in Early Hinduism], Numen, Vol. 26, Fasc. 2 (Dec., 1979), pages 192-214 Baudhayana Dharmasastra describes ‘‘Svadhyaya’’, in verse 2.6.11, as the path to [[Brahman]] (Highest Reality, Universal Spirit, Eternal Self). {{IAST|Svādhyāya}} is mentioned as one of the virtues in ''[[Bhagavad Gita]]'' 16.1.For text of BG 16.1 and translation of ''{{IAST|svādhyāya}}'' as "study of the scriptures", see: Chidbhavananda, p. 779. ''Svadhyaya'' is mentioned a second time in ''Bhagavad Gita'' verse 17.15 as a component of the discipline of one's speech by which, states the verse, " speak words that are truthful, kind, helpful, and elevates those who hear it".For text of BG 17.15 and translation of ''{{IAST|svādhyāyābhyasanaṁ}}'' as "the practice of the study of scriptures" see: {{Harvnb|Gambhīrānanda|1997|pp=644–645}}.Christopher Key Chapple (2009), ''The Bhagavad Gita: Twenty-fifth–Anniversary Edition'', State University of New York Press, {{ISBN|978-1-4384-2841-3}}, page 648 ==Svadhyaya as a historical practice== ;Learning one's Vedic recension As a tool for memorization, ''{{IAST|svādhyāya}}'' had a unique meaning for Vedic scholars as the principal tool for the [[Vedic recitation|oral preservation of the Vedas in their original form for millennia]]. When used as a formal part of scriptural study, ''{{IAST|svādhyāya}}'' involves repeated recitations of scripture for purposes of mastering the [[mantras]] with their accurate pronunciation.For traditional uses of ''{{IAST|svādhyāya}}'' in the sense of repetition of scriptural mantras for purposes of memorization, see: {{Harvnb|Arya|1986|p=6}}. The Vedas had not been committed to writing in ancient times. Almost all printed editions depend on the late manuscripts that are hardly older than 500 years, not on the still-extant and superior oral tradition.Quotation of "... almost all printed editions depend on the late manuscripts that are hardly older than 500 years, not on the still extant and superior oral tradition" is from: Witzel, M., "Vedas and {{IAST|Upaniṣads}}", in: {{Harvnb|Flood|2003|p=69}}. [[Monier Monier-Williams]] defines ''[[śruti]]'' as "sacred knowledge orally transmitted by the {{IAST|Brāhmans}} from generation to generations, the Veda".For definition of ''śruti'' as "sacred knowledge orally transmitted" see: {{Harvnb|Monier-Williams|1899|p=1101}}. [[Michael E. J. Witzel|Michael Witzel]] explains this oral tradition as follows:
The Vedic texts were orally composed and transmitted, without the use of script, in an unbroken line of transmission from teacher to student that was formalized early on. This ensured an impeccable textual transmission superior to the classical texts of other cultures; it is, in fact, something like a ''tape-recording''.... Not just the actual words, but even the long-lost musical (tonal) accent (as in old Greek or in Japanese) has been preserved up to the present.For the quotation comparing recital to a "tape-recording" see: Witzel, M., "Vedas and {{IAST|Upaniṣads}}", in: {{Harvnb|Flood|2003|pp=68–69}}."
The commentator [[Sayana|Sāyana]] discusses this term in the introduction of his commentary on the ''{{IAST|Ṛgveda}}'', in which he says that ''{{IAST|svādhyāya}}'' enables Vedic rituals ([[Yajna|yājnika karmakānda]]) to take place.For text of Sāyana commentary as ''{{IAST|karma-kārana-bhūta-svādhyāya}}'' see: {{Harvnb|Sontakke|1972|p=19}}. [[Madhvacharya|Madhva]], the [[Dvaita|dualistic]] [[Vaishnavism|Vaishnava]] philosopher, defined philosophy as the three-stage process of understanding (''{{IAST|śravaṇa}}''), reflection (''{{IAST|manana}}''), and application (''{{IAST|nididhyāsana}}''), expressing itself in two forms: study (''{{IAST|svādhyāya}}'') and teaching (''{{IAST|pravacana}}''). Of these two, Madhva considered teaching to be the highest aspect of discipline leading to [[Moksha|{{IAST|mokṣa}}]].For Madhva's threefold definition of philosophy and the twofold division of expression, see: Raghavendrachar, H. N., "Madhva's Brahma-Mīmāṁsā", in: Bhattacharyya (1956), volume 3, p. 330. Mādhavāchārya's views on svādhyāya are to be found in chapter 15 of Sarva-Darśana-Sangraha (cf. references). The ''[[Taittiriya Upanishad|Taittirīya Upanishad]]'', which belongs to the ''[[Yajurveda|Yajur Veda]]'', is still popular among those who learn [[Vedic chant]]ing.For ''{{IAST|Taittirīya Upaniṣad}}'' as part of ''Yajur Veda'', and continued popularity with students of Vedic chant, see: {{Harvnb|Gambhīrānanda|1986|p=iv}}. Recitation of mantras ([[Japa]]) is an integral part of [[Bhakti Yoga]], and in this tradition of Hinduism, it is sometimes called ''Japa Yoga''.Jennifer Munyer (2012), ''How Yoga Won the West, in Yoga-Philosophy for Everyone: Bending Mind and Body'' (Editors: Liz Swan and Fritz Allhoff), Wiley-Blackwell, {{ISBN|978-0-470-65880-2}}, pages 3-14 ===Exceptions=== There are certain days on which ''{{IAST|svādhyāya}}'' were prohibited, these were called ''{{IAST|anadhyāya}}'', after which ''{{IAST|svādhyāya}}'' must be resumed on the following day ; therefore the day of resumption is also called {{IAST|svādhyāya}}.Sanskrit English Dictionary of [[Monier-Williams]] ==Svadhyaya as a Niyama== [[File:Siddhasana.svg|thumb|Yoga meditation – a means to the virtue of Svadhyaya.]] Svādhyāya is one of the three key elements in the practice of yoga as defined in the ''[[Yoga Sutras of Patanjali]]'', appearing in the opening verse of Book two on spiritual practice and elaborated upon in two other verses.For Sanskrit text of verses 2.1, 2.32, and 2.44 and discussion as a key practice, see: {{Harvnb|Taimni|1961|pp=127–128, 220, 250}}. [[Patanjali]] mentions {{IAST|svādhyāya}} a second time as one of the five recommended observances (''[[niyama]]s''), along with purity, contentment, austerity, and self-surrender.For text and translation of YS 2.32, and translation of ''niyama'' as "observances", see: {{Harvnb|Taimni|1961|p=220}}. The five ''niyamas'', together with the five abstentions (''[[yamas]]''),For the five ''yamas'' or "restraints" as: abstention from injury (''{{IAST|ahiṁsā}}'', [[nonviolence]]), truthfulness (''satya''), non-stealing (''asteya''), control of the carnal desires and passions (''brahmacarya''), and non-acceptance of unnecessary gifts (''aparigraha''), see: Chatterjee and Datta (1984), p. 302. have been described as "'the ten commandments' of the {{IAST|Sāṁkhya-Yoga}}."For quotation including ''{{IAST|svādhyāya}}'' in the comparison to the ten commandments, see: Hiriyanna, M., "The {{IAST|Sāṁkhya}}", in: {{Harvnb|Bhattacharyya|1956|p=49}}, volume 3. The practice of Svadhyaya as a Niyama is perfected in many forms. One form of Svadhyaya is [[mantra]] meditation, where certain sound constructs pregnant with meaning are recited, anchoring the mind to one thought. This practice helps draw the mind away from outward-going tendencies, silencing the crowding of thoughts, and ultimately towards inward feeling of resonance. It can alternately be any music, sermon, chant, inspirational book that absorbs the person to a state of absorption, trance, unifying oneness.Gary Kraftsow, [http://www.yogajournal.com/article/philosophy/polishing-the-mirror/ Polishing the mirror], Yoga Journal, February 25, 2008 Svadhyaya is practiced as a self-reflection process, where one silently meditates, in [[Asana]], on one’s own behaviors, motivations and plans. Svadhyaya is, in a sense, for one’s spirit and mind a process equivalent to watching one’s body in a non-distorting mirror.G Kraftsow (2002), Yoga for Transformation: Ancient Teachings and Holistic Practices for Healing Body, Mind, and Heart, Penguin, {{ISBN|978-0140196290}}, pages 22-27 This self-study, in Yoga, is not merely contemplation of one’s own motives and behaviors, but also of one’s circumstances and the environment one is in, assessing where one is in one’s life, what is one’s life direction, if and how desirable changes may lead to a more fulfilling Self.Nina Markil, Hatha Yoga: Benefits and Principles for a More Meaningful Practice, ACSM'S Health & Fitness Journal, September/October 2010, 14(5): pp 19-24Michelle Corrigan (2010), Your Quest for a Spiritual Life: Based on the Patanjali's Yoga Sutras, {{ISBN|978-1846942952}}, pages 33-34 ==Notes== {{reflist|30em}} ==References== *{{Citation | last=Apte | first=Vaman Shivram | year=1965 | title=The Practical Sanskrit Dictionary | place=Delhi | publisher= Motilal Banarsidass | edition=Fourth Revised and Enlarged | isbn=81-208-0567-4 }} *{{Citation | last=Arya | first=Usharbudh | year=1986 | title=Yoga-Sūtras of Patañjali | place=Honesdale, Pennsylvania | publisher= The Himalayan International Institute | edition=Volume 1 | isbn=0-89389-092-8 }} *{{Citation | last = | first = | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | editor-last=Bhattacharyya | editor-first =Haridas | year =1956 | title =The Cultural Heritage of India | edition = | volume = | place = Calcutta | publisher =The Ramakrishna Mission Institute of Culture | id = | isbn = | doi = | oclc = | url = | accessdate = }}. {{Other uses|Manjira River|Manjira Wildlife Sanctuary}} {{Infobox instrument | name = Taal (instrument) | names = | image = Khuti taal.jpg | image_capt = | background = | classification = | hornbostel_sachs = | hornbostel_sachs_desc = | inventors = | developed = | range = | related = | musicians = | builders = | articles = }} The '''taal''' ({{lang-as|তাল}}; {{Lang-or|ଗିନି}}, Gini ), '''manjira''' (also spelled '''manjīrā''' or '''manjeera'''), '''jalra''', or '''gini''' is a pair of clash [[cymbal]]s,{{cite web|url=http://www.4to40.com/music/article.asp?p=Musical_Instruments_-_Solids&c=Musical_Instrument&sc=Solid_Instrument |title=Solid Instrument Article, Musical Instruments: Solids, Solid Instrument From New Delhi, Solid Instrument Musical Instrument, Popular Solid Instrument, New Delhi Based Solid Instrument |publisher=4to40.com |date=2007-03-14 |accessdate=2013-02-28}} which make high-pitched percussion sounds. In its simplest form, it consists of a pair of small hand cymbals.{{Cite book|author=Caudhurī, Vimalakānta Rôya|year=2007|title=The Dictionary Of Hindustani Classical Music|location=Delhi, India|publisher=Motilal Banarsidass|page=173|isbn=978-81-208-1708-1}}, originally published in 2000 The word taal comes from the Sanskrit word ''Tālà'', literally means a clap. It is a part of Indian music and culture, used in various traditional customs e.g. [[Bihu]] music, Harinaam etc.It is a type of Ghana vadya. In Hindu religious contexts it is known as '''karatalas''' ({{lang-sa|करताल}}, [[IAST]]: {{IAST|Karatāla}}), pronounced "karataala", (literally beat-''tala'' hand -kara), typically used to accompany devotional music such as [[bhajan]] and [[kirtan]]. They are commonly used by [[International Society for Krishna Consciousness|Hare Krishna]] devotees when performing [[harinam]], but are ubiquitous to all Hindu devotional music. ==Materials used== [[File:Manjeera or Taal.jpg|thumb|140px|Manjeera]] The clash cymbal, taal is made of bell metals i.e. bronze, brass, copper, zinc etc. Each cymbal is connected with a cord which passes through hole in its center. The pitch of different types of taal vary according to their size, weight and the materials used. A player can also adjust the timbre by varying the point of contact while playing. Manjiras are usually made of bronze, brass, copper, or zinc. The name manjira or khartal can also refer to a similar instrument made of a wooden frame with rows of cymbals inside. [[File:Vur tal.jpg|thumb|Larger version of manjira, ''Taal'']] ==Types== There are many types of Taal, categorised by size, weight and appearance. * Bortaal ({{lang-as|বৰতাল}}) is the big size clash cymbal, Its weight approx. 1½−2 kg. The player who plays Bortaal is called in Assam as ''Gayan''. Bortaal is a symbol of Assamese traditional culture. Sometimes, the players perform dance-music with both e.g. in Gayan-Bayan, Bortaal Nritya etc. Sometimes the player perform with only music e.g. in Harinaam, Dihanaam etc. The rhythmic high-pitched sound of the Bortaal makes the surroundings pure and sacred. * Majutaal ({{lang-as|মাজুতাল}}) is medium size clash cymbal, * Khutitaal or Harutaal ({{lang-as|খুটিতাল বা সৰু তাল}}) is small size clash cymbal.{{cite web|url=http://enajori.com/culture/instruments/instruments1.html |accessdate=July 24, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110701131637/http://enajori.com/culture/instruments/instruments1.html |archivedate=July 1, 2011 }} It is also known name as [[Manjira]]. It is generally used in traditional, folk and classical music in India. It is also used in dance in [[Bharat Natyam]], [[Kuchipudi]] [[Manipuri dance|Manipuri]] [[Mohiniattam]] [[Andhra Natyam]] [[Kathakali]] This Instrument has some other names e.g. thaaleaj (Kashmir), taalam, tala, jalra etc.{{cite web|last=Courtney |first=David |url=http://chandrakantha.com/articles/indian_music/manjira.html |title=Manjira – Indian hand cymbals |publisher=Chandrakantha.com |date= |accessdate=2013-02-28}} * Ramtaal or Khoritaal ({{lang-as|ৰামতাল বা খৰিতাল}}) are two wooden handled musical instruments, containing multiple pairs of small cymbals. It is generally known India as [[Karatalas|Khartal]]. ==Uses== Manjiras are commonly played in folk and [[devotional music]]. They are played in various religious events and ceremonies in India and especially in [[bhajans]]. Manjiras are ancient musical instruments. Manjiras can be seen in many ancient temple pictures. ===Gujarati folk music=== Manjiras have a significant importance in [[Gujarat]]i and [[Marathi language|Marathi]] folk music. In [[Maharashtra]] they are known as Taal (टाळ). Initially Manjiras were played in [[aarti]]. In [[Gujarat]] and [[Maharashtra]], manjiras hold great importance and are played in [[bhajan]], [[santvani]] and [[dayro]]. ==See also== *[[Bihu]] *[[Bihu dance]] *[[Culture of Assam]] *[[Clash cymbals]] ===Other instruments in Hindu=== *[[Bhajan]] *[[Khol]] *[[Maddale]], an instrument used in [[Yakshagana]] *[[Manjira]] *[[Mrdanga]] *[[Mridangam]] *[[Tabla]] *[[Thavil]] *[[Tingsha]] Gadam

The [[Hebrew Bible]] and the [[New Testament]] contain many passages outlining approaches to, and descriptions of, [[Violence|violent]] activities, centering on the [[History of ancient Israel and Judah|ancient nation of Israel]] and their involvement with [[Gentile]] nations. They also provide civil guidelines on the subject of violent activity as it pertains to individuals within the nation, distinguishing individualistic from [[Nationalism|nationalistic]] actions.
These texts contain [[narrative]]s, [[poetry]], and instruction describing, commanding, or condemning violent actions by God, individuals, groups, and governments. These actions include war, human and animal sacrifice, murder, rape, stoning, sexism, slavery, criminal punishment, and violent language.<ref name=CreachResources>{{cite book | last = Creach | first = "Jerome F. D." | title = Violence in Scripture: Resources for the Use of Scripture in the Church | year=2013| publisher=Westminster John Knox Press|location=Louisville, Kentucky| isbn=978-0-664-23145-3}}</ref>{{rp|Introduction}} The texts have a history of interpretation within the [[Abrahamic religions]] and Western culture that includes justification for acts of violence as well as [[structural violence]], and have also been used in opposition to violence.<ref name="George P. Fletcher">{{citebook| author1-last=Fletcher| author1-first=George P.| author2-last=Olin| author2-first="Jens David"| title=Humanity, When Force is Justified and Why | publisher=Oxford University Press,Inc | location=New York, New York | isbn=978-0-19-518308-5 | page=50}}</ref>
==In the Hebrew Bible== {{Main|Hebrew Bible}}
===Terms=== {{Bible sidebar |expanded=interpretation}} ''Hamas'', meaning violence or wrong, is the Hebrew Bible's primary term for violence and is first used in Genesis 6:11: "the earth was corrupt in God's sight, and the earth was filled with ''violence'' (hamas)."<ref name="David J.A. Clines">{{cite book|last=Clines|first=David J.A.|title=The Dictionary of Classical Hebrew| volume=Volumes III and IV}}</ref>{{rp|256}}<ref name = CreachResources/>{{rp|5}} It occurs sixty times in the Hebrew Bible, is almost always used to identify physical violence (Gen.49:5; Judges 9:24), and is used to describe human, not divine, violence.<ref name=CreachOxford>{{cite web|url=http://religion.oxfordre.com/view/10.1093/acrefore/9780199340378.001.0001/acrefore-9780199340378-e-154|title=Violence in the Old Testament |last=Creach| first=Jerome| date=Jul 2016| work=The Oxford Research Encyclopedia of Religion| publisher=Oxford University Press|access-date=23 December 2017|doi=10.1093/acrefore/9780199340378.001.0001/acrefore-9780199340378-e-154 |doi-broken-date=2018-04-11 }}</ref>{{rp|2}}<ref name="Daniel I. Block">{{cite book| last =Block| first =Daniel I.| title=The Book of Ezekiel, Chapters 1 24| year=1997| publisher=Eerdman's| location=Grand Rapids, Michigan|isbn=0-8028-2535-4| page=267}}</ref> "Sometimes the word refers to extreme wickedness (Isaiah 53:8; 59:6) where physical violence may or may not be [involved]."<ref name="Preston Sprinkle">{{cite book| last=Sprinkle| first=Preston| title=Fight: A Christian Case for Non-Violence| year=2013| publisher=David C. Cook| location=Colorado Springs, Colorado| isbn=978-1-4347-0492-4| page =278}}</ref><ref name="Brenneman">{{cite book|editor1-last=Brenneman| editor1-first = Laura|editor2-last=Schantz| editor2-first=Brad D.|title=Struggles for Shalom: Peace and Violence across the Testaments| year=2014| publisher=Wipf and Stock| location=Eugene, Oregon| isbn=978-1-62032-622-0| chapter=Chapter 2 Willard Swartley| page =18}}=</ref><ref name = CreachResources/>{{rp|10–11}}<ref name="Jacob L. Wright">{{Cite Journal | last =Wright | first = Jacob L.|title = Warfare and Wanton Destruction: A Reexamination of Deuteronomy 19:19–20 in Relation to Ancient Siegecraft | year = 2008 | volume = 127.3 | journal = Journal of Biblical Literature |pages=423–458}}</ref> As a result, ''hamas'' may also refer to verbal, or even ethical violence.<ref>{{cite book|author1=G. Johannes Botterweck |author2=Helmer Ringgren|title=Theological Dictionary of the Old Testament|volume=4|pages=478–87|publisher= Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing|year= 1979|isbn= 0802823270}}</ref> "The term Hamas sometimes appears as a cry to God in the face of injustice (Jer. 6:7)." Exodus 23:1 and Deut. 19:16 characterize a false witness as ʿēd ḥāmas (a “violent witness”). The notion that a false witness threatens life and well-being appears in fuller form in the Psalter."<ref name=CreachOxford/>{{rp|3}}<ref name="H.J. Stroebe">{{cite article | last = Stroebe | first = H. J. | editor = Ernst Jenni and Claus Westermann | title = “חמס ḥāmas, violence” | series = Theological Lexicon of the Old Testament translated by Mark Biddle in 3 vols. | volume = 1 | year = 1997 | publisher =Hendrickson | location = Peabody, MA |pages = 437–439}}</ref>
Within the [[Pentateuch]] the terms ''gazal'' (rob) and ''asaq'' (oppress) are frequently used in combination to describe the human violence of taking/robbing/plundering as [[oppression]] of the poor which may or may not include physical, verbal or other types of harm. They are also used both separately and in combination throughout the remainder of the Hebrew Bible describing robbing the poor (Isaiah 3:14, 10:2; Jeremiah 22:3; Micah 2:2, 3:2; Malachi 1:3), withholding the wages of a hired person (cf. Deuteronomy 24:14), political oppression (Hosea 12:7), charging oppressive interest (Ezekiel 22:12), and oppressing the outsider in their midst (Ezekiel 22:7) as acts of violence.<ref name="David J.A. Clines"/>
"The Hebrew ''verb'' ḥāram connotes [complete annihilation] (New Revised Standard Version, “utterly destroy”; Deut. 7:2); the noun that derives from it [[herem (war or property)|ḥērem]]<ref name=CreachOxford/> is sometimes translated as "the ban" and denotes the separation, exclusion and dedication of persons or objects to God which may be set apart for destruction (Deuteronomy 7:26; Leviticus 27:28-29).<ref name="David J.A. Clines"/>{{rp|319}}<ref name="Norbert Lohfink">{{cite book | last =Lohfink | first =Norbert| editors = by G. Johannes Botterweck and Helmer Ringgren| title= ḥāram in Theological Dictionary of the Old Testament, | publisher = Eerdmans | location = Grand Rapids, MI | year =1986 | page = 197}}</ref> Historian Susan Niditch says "the root h-r-m links together several biblical non-war and war usages of the term ... under the heading of ''sacrifice''."<ref name="Susan Niditch">{{cite book| last=Niditch| first=Susan|title=War in the Hebrew Bible: A Study in the Ethics of Violence| year=1993| publisher=Oxford University Press| location=New York|isbn=0-19-507638-9|pages=29–31}}</ref> Early use of the term indicates the Israelites were not allowed to touch, possess, or redeem these "devoted things".<ref name="Philip D. Stern">{{cite book | last = Stern | first = Philip D. | title =The Biblical Ḥērem: A Window on Israel’s Religious Experience | series = Brown Judaic Studies | volume = 211 | year = 1991 | publisher = Scholars Press | location =Atlanta | page =173}}</ref> However, later use of the term, such as in Numbers 18:14-17 and Deuteronomy 7, indicates items and first born children set aside as ''herem'' were to be redeemed by the Priests.<ref name="Susan Niditch"/>{{rp|30}} Hebrew scholar Baruch A. Levine says Exodus 33:5-16 is an example of early Hebrew ideology while noting Deut.7:1-11 contains much the same ideology with the addition of the ban (see also Exodus 20:19,20). Levine concludes this is one of several indications, including extra-biblical evidence, that ''herem'' was a later addition to Hebrew thought.<ref name="Baruch A. Levine">{{cite book| editor1-last=Chazan| editor1-first=Robert| editor2-last=Hallo| editor2-first=William W. | editor3-last=Schiffman| editor3-first=Lawrence H.| title =כי ברוך הוא: Ancient Near Eastern, Biblical, and Judaic Studies in Honor of Baruch A. Levine| year=1999| publisher=Eisenbrauns| location=Winona Lake, Indiana| isbn=1-57506-030-2| pages=396–397}}</ref> Levine says this is indicative that Israel was still, as late as Deuteronomy, making ideological adjustments to having imported the foreign practice of ''herem'' from its source in the surrounding Near Eastern nations."<ref name="Baruch A. Levine"/>{{rp|396}}
Over half the occurrences of the verb and noun for the root ''ḥ-r-m'' are concerned with the destruction of nations in war, but other terms associated with what Old Testament scholar Eric Siebert describes as "divine violence" may or may not include war. Siebert says divine violence is "violence God is said to have perpetrated, caused, or sanctioned." Specifically, this includes (1) violence God commits without using human agents (e.g., sending down fire on Sodom and Gomorrah); (2) violence God commissions, typically unbeknownst to those being commissioned (e.g., using Babylon to punish Judah for their sins); and (3) violence God commands directly (e.g., ordering [[Israelites]] to wipe out [[Canaanites]])."<ref name="Eric Siebert">{{cite journal|last1=Seibert|first1=Eric A.|title=Recent Research on Divine Violence in the Old Testament (with Special Attention to Christian Theological Perspectives)|journal=Currents in Biblical Research|date=21 October 2016|volume=15|issue=1|pages=8–40|doi=10.1177/1476993X15600588}}</ref> For example, concerning those who worship idols, Deuteronomy 7:16 uses ''akal'' ("consume") when saying "You must ''destroy'' (consume) all the peoples the Lord your God gives over to you…". Deuteronomy 7:24, on the other hand, uses ''abad'' when saying "you shall make their name ''perish'' from under heaven…" while Deuteronomy 20:10-18 says "…you shall not leave alive anything that breathes. But you shall utterly destroy (''ha-harem taharimem'') them, the Hittite and the Amorite, the Canaanite and the Perizzite, the Hivite and the Jebusite, as the Lord your God has commanded you…". "Amos 1:3–2:3 uses akal to indict Israel’s neighbors for various acts of cruelty during war (e.g., the Ammonites “ripped open pregnant women in Gilead in order to enlarge their territory”; 1:13) and uses those [[war crime]]s of surrounding peoples to draw a parallel with Israel’s mistreatment of the poor, thus elevating economic injustice to the level of war crimes." (2:6–8).<ref name=CreachResources/>{{rp|44}}
Other terms are: ''ṣamat'' (put an end to, exterminate...annihilate); ''shamad'' (destroy, exterminate); ''nakah'' (to strike fatally, kill, in manslaughter, murder...as retaliation ...in warfare, conquest...combat...attack, rout); ''aqar'' (pluck up, often in the violent sense); ''qatsah'' (to cut off, in a destructive sense); ''shabat'' (with zeker can refer to one's "memory" being "blotted out" but in another idiom it means to "be blotted out...from...[the] earth" to "be exterminated, be destroyed, perish"; and ''kalah'' (kalah in Qal can mean "be finished, be destroyed).<ref name="David J.A. Clines"/>{{rp|133,431–432,684,179,255,416,418}}
===Biblical narrative=== ====Book of Genesis==== [[File:The Phillip Medhurst Picture Torah 53. Noah's Ark and the Deluge. Genesis cap 7 v 12. Hoet.jpg|left|thumb|Noah's Ark and the Deluge.]] When [[Fall of man|Adam and Eve disobey God]], he [[curse]]s them and banishes them from the [[Garden of Eden]] ([[Book of Genesis|Genesis]] 3). In Genesis 4:1-18 [[Cain and Abel|Cain, the first born man, murders his brother Abel]]. God curses Cain for this, and also grants him protection from danger.<ref name=CreachTheology>{{cite book|last=Creach|first=Jerome|title=Theology of Violence|year=2013| publisher=Westminster John Knox Press|location=Louisville, Kentucky|isbn=978-0-664-23145-3|pages=30–32}}</ref>
In the [[Genesis flood narrative]] (Genesis 6-9), God sees that "wickedness of man was great" and decides to exterminate mankind and all animals, saving only [[Noah]] and those he brought with him on the [[Noah's Ark|Ark]]. After the Flood, God promises to never again destroy all life by a flood.<ref name=CreachTheology/>{{rp|34–41}}<ref name=Siebert>{{cite book|last=Siebert|first=Eric A.| title=The Violence of Scripture: Overcoming the Old Testament's Troubling Legacy| year=2012|publisher =Fortress Press|location=Minneapolis,Minnesota|isbn=978-1-4514-2432-4|page=43,83}}</ref><ref name = "Florentino García Martínez">{{cite book| editor1-last=Martínez| editor1-first=Florentino García| editor2-last=Luttikhuizen| editor2-first=Gerardus Petrus| title=Interpretations of the Flood| year=1998| publisher=Brill| location=Boston| isbn=90-04-11253-7|page=147}}</ref> [[File:Pieter Schoubroeck - De verwoesting van Sodom en Gomorra.jpg|thumb|[[Pieter Schoubroeck]] - The Destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah, c.1600]] In Genesis 18-19 God resolves to destroy the cities [[Sodom and Gomorrah]], "because their sin is very grievous". God promises [[Abraham]] that he will spare Sodom if as few as 10 righteous people can be found there. The cities are destroyed, but angels save Abraham's nephew [[Lot (biblical person)|Lot]] and most of his family from the destruction.<ref name="Eric A. Siebert">{{cite book|last=Siebert|first=Eric A.| title =Disturbing Divine Behavior| year=2009|publisher=Fortress Press| location=Minneapolis,Minnesota|isbn=978-0-8006-6344-5|page=21,22}}</ref> God tests Abraham by demanding that he [[Binding of Isaac|sacrifice Isaac]], his son (Genesis 22). As Abraham is about to lay the knife upon his son, God restrains him, promising him numberless descendants.<ref name =CreachTheology/>{{rp|42,46}}
Isaac's son [[Jacob]] [[Jacob and Esau|conspires to gain]] his elder brother [[Esau]]'s birthright, but the brothers ultimately reconcile (Genesis 25-33). In Genesis 32:22-32, [[Jacob]] meets and [[Jacob wrestling with the angel|wrestles with someone]], a man, angel or God, who blesses him and gives him the name [[Israel (name)|Israel]].<ref name="Mark Sheridan">{{cite book|editor1-last=Sheridan|editor1-first=Mark|editor2-last=Oden|editor2-first="Thomas C."| title=Ancient Christian Commentary on Scripture; Old Testament II, Genesis 12-50| year=2002| publisher=Inter-Varsity Press| location=Downer's Grove, Illinois|isbn=0-8308-1472-8|page=220}}</ref>
[[Joseph (Genesis)|Joseph]] (Genesis 37-50), Jacob's favorite son, is sold into slavery in Egypt by his jealous brothers. Joseph prospers after hardship, with God's guidance, and saves his family from starvation.<ref name="Donald B. Redford">{{cite book|last=Redford|first=Donald B.| title=A Study of the Biblical Story of Joseph: (Genesis 37-50)| year=1970| publisher=E.J.Brill| location=Leiden, Netherlands|pages=133–134}}</ref>
====Book of Exodus and Book of Leviticus==== [[File:Lamentations over the Death of the First-Born of Egypt by Charles Sprague Pearce.JPG|thumb|right|''Lamentations over the Death of the First-Born of Egypt'' by [[Charles Sprague Pearce]] (1877)]] A new [[Pharaohs in the Bible#Pharaohs in the Book of Exodus|pharaoh]] ([[Book of Exodus|Exodus]] 1) sees that the [[Israelites]] in Egypt have become many and fears they might aid Egypt's enemies. The Egyptians make the Israelites "serve with rigour" and their lives become "bitter with hard service".<ref name="Robert Kugler">{{cite book|author1-last=Kugler| author1-first=Robert| author2-last=Hartin| author2-first=Patrick| title=An Introduction to the Bible| year=2009| publisher=Eerdman's Pub.Co.| location=Grand Rapids, Michigan| isbn=978-0-8028-4636-5| page=62}}</ref> Pharaoh orders two Hebrew midwives, [[Shiphrah]] and [[Puah]], to kill the newborn sons of Hebrew women, but they disobey him. Pharaoh then orders his people to drown these children.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt0201.htm|title=Exodus 1 / Hebrew - English Bible / Mechon-Mamre|website=www.mechon-mamre.org|accessdate=17 December 2017}}</ref>
[[Moses]], a Hebrew [[Finding of Moses|raised by]] [[Bithiah|Pharaoh's daughter]], one day encounters an Egyptian beating a Hebrew. He slays the Egyptian and flees Egypt. God hears the plight of the Israelites and sends Moses back to Egypt to bring them out of that land to [[Canaan]]. At one point during the journey back, God intends to kill Moses, but he is [[Zipporah at the inn|saved by his wife Zipporah]] (Exodus 2-4).<ref name=Segal>{{cite book|last=Segal|first=Joseph M.|title=Joseph's Bones:Understanding the Struggle Between God and Mankind in the Bible| year=2007| publisher=Riverhead Books: The Penguin Group| location=New York|page=437}}</ref>
Moses asks Pharaoh to release the Israelites, but Pharaoh responds by [[Bricks without straw|demanding more work]] from them. Moses repeats his request several times as the [[Plagues of Egypt]] afflict the Egyptians, but God makes Pharaoh refuse until the tenth plague, when God kills all firstborn people and cattle in Egypt, apart from those of the Israelites, who are [[Plagues_of_Egypt#10._Death_of_firstborn_.28.D7.9E.D6.B7.D7.9B.D6.B7.D6.BC.D7.AA_.D7.91.D6.B0.D6.BC.D7.9B.D7.95.D6.B9.D7.A8.D7.95.D6.B9.D7.AA.29:_Ex._11:1.E2.80.9312:36|protected]]. The Israelites are allowed to leave, but God again changes Pharaoh's mind, and an army is sent after them. God saves them from the army by [[Crossing the Red Sea|drowning it in the Red Sea]].<ref name=Gowen>{{cite book| last=Gowen| first=Donald E.| title=Theology in Exodus: Biblical Theology in the Form of a Commentary| year=1994| publisher = Westminster John Knox Press| location=Louisville, Kentucky| isbn=0-664-22057-6| pages=127–129}}</ref>
At [[Biblical Mount Sinai|Mount Sinai]], God gives the Israelites the [[Ten Commandments]] and the [[Covenant Code]] (Exodus 20-23). These laws include [[thou shalt not kill]], [[eye for an eye]] and laws about [[The Bible and slavery|slavery]] and other things. [[List of capital crimes in the Torah|Capital punishment]] is prescribed for some crimes. [[Animal sacrifice]] in the form of [[Burnt offering (Judaism)|burnt offering]]s is mentioned, and it is prescribed that an ox that kills a person is to be stoned. The Code states that "And a stranger shalt thou not wrong, neither shalt thou oppress him; for ye were strangers in the land of Egypt." and "Ye shall not afflict any widow, or fatherless child." The Israelites promise to follow these laws (Exodus 24:3).<ref name="Christopher B. Hayes">{{cite book| last=Hays | first = Christopher B.| title= Hidden Riches: A Sourcebook for the Comparative Study of the Hebrew Bible and Ancient Near East| year=2014 | publisher =Westminster John Knox Press| location= Loisville, Kentucky| isbn=978-0-664-23701-1| page=140}}</ref>
The Israelites break their promise by worshiping the [[Golden Calf]]. God is angered by this and intends to "consume them", but Moses persuades him not to do so. Moses is also angered, and he breaks two stone tablets with God's writing. On Moses' command, the [[Levites]] kill about three thousand people (Exodus 32).<ref name="Karla R. Suomala">{{cite book| last = Suomala| first= Karla R.| title= Moses and God in Dialogue: Exodus 32-34 in Postbiblical Literature| year=2004| publisher = Peter Lang Publishing Inc.| location=New York| isbn=0-8204-6905-X|page=147}}</ref>
God has Moses make new stone tablets, and gives Moses the [[Ritual Decalogue]], which states in part "Take heed to thyself, lest thou make a covenant with the inhabitants of the land whither thou goest, lest they be for a snare in the midst of thee. But ye shall break down their altars, and dash in pieces their pillars, and ye shall cut down their [[Asherah pole|Asherim]]" (Exodus 34).<ref name="William J. Doorly">{{cite book| last=Doorly| first= William J.| title=The Laws of Yahweh: A Handbook of Biblical Law| year=2002| publisher= Paulist Press| location=New York| isbn=0-8091-4037-3| pages=100–106}}</ref>
The [[Book of Leviticus]] sets out detailed rules for animal sacrifice. The [[Holiness code]], Leviticus 17-26, sets out a list of prohibitions, and the punishments for breaking them. Punishments include execution, sometimes by [[Stoning#Judaism|stoning]] or [[Death by burning|burning]].<ref name="Jan Joosten">{{cite book| last=Joosten| first=Jan|title=People and Land in the Holiness Code: An Exegetical Study of the Ideational Framework of the Law in Leviticus 17-26 |year=1996| publisher=E.J.Brill| location=New York| isbn=90-04-10557-3| pages=2–5}}</ref>
====Book of Numbers==== [[File:Tissot The Sabbath-Breaker Stoned.jpg|thumb|The Sabbath-breaker Stoned [[James Tissot]] c.1900]] [[File:Tissot The Women of Midian Led Captive by the Hebrews.jpg|thumb|The Women of Midian Led Captive by the Hebrews James Tissot c.1900]] God orders Moses to count "all that are able to go forth to war in Israel" ([[Book of Numbers|Numbers]] 1).<ref name="Timothy R. Ashley">{{cite book| last=Ashley| first=Timothy R.|title=The Books of Numbers| year=1993| publisher=Eerdmans Publishing| location=Grand Rapids, Michigan| isbn=0-8028-2523-0| page=51}}</ref> God hears the people "speaking evil" and punishes them with fire. Moses prays, and the fire abates.<ref name="Timothy R. Ashley"/>{{rp|200–202}} God is again angered and sends "a great plague" (Numbers 11). God hears [[Miriam]] and [[Aaron]] speak against Moses, and punishes Miriam with [[leprosy]].<ref name="Timothy R. Ashley"/>{{rp|227}} Moses asks God to heal her which he does (Numbers 12).<ref name="Daniel B. Kohn">{{cite book| last=Kohn|first = Daniel B.| title=Sex, Drugs, and Violence in the Jewish Tradition: Moral Perspectives| year=2004| publisher=Jason Aronson| location=New York| isbn=0-7657-6180-7| page =47,48}}</ref>
The Israelites reach the border of Canaan, but [[The Twelve Spies|due to reports from spies]] they refuse to enter, and wish to return to Egypt.<ref name="Timothy Walton">{{cite book| last=Walton| first=Timothy| title=Challenges in Intelligence Analysis: Lessons from 1300 BCE to the Present| year=2010| publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=New York| isbn=978-0-521-76441-4|pages=31–33}}</ref> God is angered, and tells Moses "I will smite them with the pestilence, and destroy them, and will make of thee a nation greater and mightier than they." Moses persuades him not to, but God declares that the Israelites will now wander the wilderness for forty years before they can enter Canaan.<ref name="Michael Carasik">{{cite book| last=Carasik| first=Michael| title=מקראות גדולות: Numbers: The Rubin JPS Miqra'ot Gedolot| year=2011| publisher=The Jewish Publication Society|location=Philadelphia, Pa. | isbn=978-0-8276-0921-1|page=100}}</ref> They are attacked by [[Amalekites]] and [[Canaanites]] (Numbers 13-14). In Numbers 15, a man is found working on the [[Sabbath]]. God orders him to be killed and he is stoned.<ref name="Richard H. Hiers">{{cite book| last=Hiers |first=Richard H.| title=Justice and Compassion in Biblical Law| year=2009| publisher = Continuum| location=New York| page=115}}</ref>
[[Korah#Korah.2C son of Izhar.2C leader of a rebellion against Moses|Korah]] and a group of men rebel against Moses and Aaron.<ref name="Adriane Leveen">{{cite book|last=Leveen| first=Adriane| title=Memory and Tradition in the Book of Numbers| year=2008| publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=New York|isbn=978-0521-87869-2|page=215}}</ref> God destroys them (Numbers 16). The Isralites "murmur" about this, and God punishes them with a plague (Numbers 16).<ref name="Calum Carmichael">{{cite book|last=Carmichael| first=Calum| title=The Book of Numbers: A Critique of Genesis| year=2012| publisher=Yale University Press|location=New Haven, Connecticut| isbn=978-0-300-17918-7|pages=90–95}}</ref> At [[Hormah]], a Canaanite king fights the Israelites, and the Israelites promise God that if he gives them victory over this people, they will destroy their cities. He does and they do.<ref name="William Smith">{{cite book| last=Smith| first = William| title=The Book of Moses; Or, the Pentateuch in Its Authorship, Credibility and Civilization| year=1868| publisher=Longman's, Green and Co.| location=London, England|pages=456–458}}</ref> The Israelites speak against God and Moses, and God sends [[Fiery flying serpent|venomous snakes]] that kill many of them. Moses prays for the people, and God helps them (Numbers 21).<ref name="Joseph T. Lienhard">{{cite book| editor1-last=Lienhard| editor1-first=Joseph T.|editor2-last=Oden|editor2-first=Thomas C.|title=Exodus, Leviticus, Numbers, Deuteronomy|year=2001|publisher=Inter Varsity Press|location=Downer's Grove, Illinois| isbn=978-0-8308-9728-5| page=241,242}}</ref>
The Israelites conquer the cities of [[Sihon]], king of the Amorites, and they "smote him, and his sons, and all his people, until there was none left him remaining; and they possessed his land." (Numbers 21).<ref name="Rolf P. Knierim">{{cite book| author1-last=Knierim| author1-first=Rolf P.| author2-last=Coats| author2-first=George W.|title=Numbers|volume=4 The Forms of the Old Testament Literature| year=2005| publisher=Eerdman's|location=Grand Rapids Michigan| isbn=0-8028-2231-2| page=243}}</ref> When the diviner [[Balaam]] beats his donkey, it speaks. Balaam later prophesise on the future of the Israelite's enemies (Numbers 22-24).<ref name="Joseph T. Lienhard"/>{{rp|244}}
Some Israelites commit harlotry with women in [[Moab#Biblical and other narratives|Moab]], and sacrifice to their gods. God is angered, orders executions and sends a plague, but "the main guilt is Midian's and on Midian fell the vengeance" (Numbers 25 and 31).<ref name="Anthony Rees">{{cite book| last=Rees| first =Anthony| title=[Re]Reading Again: A Mosaic Reading of Numbers 25| year=2015| publisher =Bloomsbury, T&T Clark|location=New York| isbn=978-0-56755-436-9|pages=18–20, 23}}</ref>
God orders Moses to "Harass the [[Midian#In the Bible|Midianites]], and smite them", and to again count "all that are able to go forth to war in Israel" (Numbers 25-26).<ref name="Anthony Rees"/>{{rp|100}} The Isralites [[Midian war|war against Midian]], and "slew every male". They take captive the women and children, and take all cattle, flocks and goods as loot, and burn all cities and camps. When they return to Moses, he is angered, and commands "Now therefore kill every male among the little ones, and kill every woman that hath known man by lying with him. But all the women children, that have not known man by lying with him, keep alive for yourselves" (Numbers 31).<ref name="Dennis Olson">{{cite book| last=Olson| first = Dennis| title=Interpretation: a Bible Commentary for Teaching and Preaching Numbers| year=1989| publisher=Westminster John Knox Press| location=Louisville, Kentucky| isbn=0-8042-3104-4| pages=176–178}}</ref>
God tells Moses "Speak unto the children of Israel, and say unto them: When ye pass over the Jordan into the land of Canaan, then ye shall drive out all the inhabitants of the land from before you, and destroy all their figured stones, and destroy all their molten images, and demolish all their high places. And ye shall drive out the inhabitants of the land, and dwell therein; for unto you have I given the land to possess it." and "But if ye will not drive out the inhabitants of the land from before you, then shall those that ye let remain of them be as thorns in your eyes, and as pricks in your sides, and they shall harass you in the land wherein ye dwell. And it shall come to pass, that as I thought to do unto them, so will I do unto you" (Numbers 33).<ref name="Walter Riggans">{{cite book| last =Riggans|first=Walter|title= Numbers| year=1983|publisher=Westminster John Knox Press| location=Louisville, Kentucky| isbn=0-664-21393-6| page=235}}</ref>
====Book of Deuteronomy==== [[Deuteronomy]] begins with a review of previous stories, including a battle between the Israelites and the Amorites (Deuteronomy 1:41-44), and the destruction of [[Rephaim]] by the Ammonites with Yahweh's help (2:21), along with similar other displacements.<ref name="Peter C. Craigie">{{cite book| last=Craigie| first=Peter C.| title=The Book of Deuteronomy| year=1976| publisher=Eerdman's| location=Grand Rapids, Michigan| isbn=0-8028-2524-9|pages=106}}</ref> Deuteronomy 2:31-37 records the complete extermination of the people ruled by Sihon king of Heshbon. Similar treatment, at Yahweh's command, was given to the people under Og king of Bashan.<ref name="Peter C. Craigie"/>{{rp|122}} Moses also recounts how God destroyed the followers of Baal-Peor, and threatens to destroy the Israelites if they return to idolatry. Similar threats of destruction for disobedience, or idolatry more specifically, can be found in Deuteronomy 6, 8, 11. On the other hand, God promises that if his people obey him he will give them victory in fighting their enemies in Deuteronomy 6, 11.<ref name="Peter C. Craigie"/>{{rp|327}}
Deuteronomy provides legislation to protect perpetrators of unintentional homicide from revenge killings (4, 19). The Ten Commandments prohibit murder (5:17).<ref name="Gary Harlan Hall">{{cite book|last=Hall| first= "Gary Harlan"| title=The College Press NIV Commentary Deuteronomy| year=2000| publisher=College Press Publishing| location=Joplin, Missouri|isbn=0-89900-879-8| page=91,298}}</ref> Deuteronomy 7 orders the complete annihilation of the indigenous inhabitants of Canaan, and God promises in exchange for obedience to bring diseases on the enemies of Israel.<ref name="Gary Harlan Hall"/>{{rp|150}} Chapter 9 records an incident in which Yahweh was angry and intended to destroy the Israelites, but was dissuaded by Moses.<ref name="Gary Harlan Hall"/>{{rp|183}} Deuteronomy 12 records Yahweh's displeasure at the practice of burning sons and daughters as offerings to deities. Deuteronomy 13 insists that those who advocate the worship of other deities must be killed, and that a town that worships other deities must be entirely exterminated, including its livestock. Deuteronomy 14 forbids self-mutilation. Deuteronomy 17 punishes anyone who worships any deity or feature of the natural world with stoning to death, and likewise imposes the death penalty on anyone who disobeys the judicial decision of a priest.<ref name="Bernard M. Levinson">{{cite book| last=Levinson| first=Bernard M.| title=Deuteronomy and the Hermeneutics of Legal Innovation| year=1997| publisher=Oxford University Press| location=New York| isbn=0-19-511280-6| pages=26–52}}</ref>
Deuteronomy 19 imposes the death penalty for premeditated murder, establishes cities of refuge, and also imposes the ''lex talionis'': "life for life, eye for eye, tooth for tooth, hand for hand, foot for foot" limiting vengeance (verse 21, NRSV).<ref name="Gary Harlan Hall"/>{{rp|297–299}} Deuteronomy 20 regulates warfare, allowing for various exemptions from military service, and mandating that a city which Israel fights (outside of Canaan) should have all of its males slaughtered, with women taken as spoils of war. The Canaanites, on the other hand, are to be completely exterminated (20) exempting only the fruit trees.<ref name="Gary Harlan Hall"/>{{rp|310–311}} Deuteronomy 21 commands the use of sacrifices to atone for blood in cases where a murderer cannot be identified, and mandates a month-long period of mourning before an Israelite warrior can have sexual relations with a female captive. It also mandates the stoning to death of rebellious children. Deuteronomy 22 orders the killing of women who cannot prove that they were virgins on their wedding night, and of both the man and woman when a man sleeps with another man's wife. It also mandates the death penalty for a man who has sexual relations with a betrothed virgin, and of the virgin if she does not cry out for help when raped.<ref name="Gary Harlan Hall"/>{{rp|312–344}}
Deuteronomy 24 imposes the death penalty for the kidnapping of a fellow Israelite, and forbids putting parents to death for crimes committed by their children, and vice versa.<ref name="Gary Harlan Hall"/>{{rp|367–370}} Deuteronomy 25 allows for judges to have people punished in legal disputes by flogging, but limits the number of strikes to forty. "If men get into a fight with one another, and the wife of one intervenes to rescue her husband from the grip of his opponent by reaching out and seizing his genitals, you shall cut off her hand; show no pity" (25:11-12).<ref>https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Deuteronomy+25&version=NIV</ref><ref name="Cheryl B. Anderson">{{cite book|last=Anderson| first =Cheryl B.| title=Women, Ideology and Violence Critical Theory and the Construction of Gender in the Book of the Covenant and Deuteronomic Law| year=2004| publisher=T7T Clark International| location=New York|isbn=0-5670-8252-0| page=122}}</ref> This chapter also urges the extermination of the Amalekites (verses 17-19). Deuteronomy 28 contains blessing and curses: blessing, including the defeat of Israel's enemies, if Israel obeys; and curses if Israel disobeys. These curses include disease, famine, defeat and death in warfare, insanity, abuse and robbery, enslavement, and cannibalism due to extreme hunger. Similar threats appear in the following chapter (29) and in Deuteronomy 32.<ref name="Abraham Joshua Heschel">{{cite book|last =Heschel| first=Abraham Joshua| title=Heavenly Torah: As Refracted Through the Generations| year=2006| publisher=The Continuum International Publishing Group| location=New York| isbn=0-8264-0802-8| pages=452–457}}</ref>
====Book of Joshua==== [[File:Prise de Jéricho.jpg|thumb|''The Taking of Jericho'' ([[Jean Fouquet]], c.1452–1460)]] God commands [[Joshua]] to take possession of Canaan ([[Book of Joshua|Joshua]] 1). The Jericho-woman [[Rahab]] aids two Israelite spies, and she and her family are promised to be spared in the coming conquest.<ref name="David T. Lamb">{{cite book|last=Lamb|first=David T.|title=God Behaving Badly: Is the God of the Old Testament Angry, Sexist and Racist?|year=2011|publisher=InterVarsity Press|location=Downer's Grove, Illinois|isbn=978-0-8308-3826-4|page=80}}</ref> The Israelites enter Canaan, carrying with them the [[Ark of the Covenant]].<ref name="David T. Lamb"/>{{rp|31}} Joshua [[Battle of Jericho|conquers the city of Jericho]]. The city is burned, and apart from Rahab´s family, every person, ox, sheep and donkey is killed (Joshua 6).<ref name="David T. Lamb"/>{{rp|100,101}} Joshua attempts to capture the city of [[Ai (Canaan)|Ai]], but fails (Joshua 7). A second attempt, advised by God, succeeds. The city is set on fire and all the inhabitants are killed (Joshua 8).<ref name="Richard A. Gabriel">{{cite book|last=Gabriel|first=Richard A.|title=The Military History of Ancient Israel|year=2003|publisher=Praeger Publishers|location=Westport, Connecticut|isbn=0-275-97798-6|pages=133–137}}</ref>
Several kings ally together to fight the Israelites. The people of [[Gibeon (ancient city)#Canaanite Gibeon|Gibeon]], learning of the city's destruction, tricks the Israelites into a peace-treaty.<ref name="Richard A. Gabriel"/>{{rp|140–142}} When Joshua learns of the trickery, he curses the Gibeonites (Joshua 9).<ref name="Richard A. Gabriel"/>{{rp|133}} When the king of Jerusalem hears of the treaty, he and several other kings attack Gibeon, who then call on Joshua for help. God attacks Joshua's enemies with hailstones, the Israelites are victorious, and the enemy kings are captured.<ref name="Warren W. Wiersbe">{{cite book|last=Wiersbe|first=Warren W.|title=The Bible Exposition Commentary Old Testament History|year=2003|publisher=Victor Publishing|location=Eastbourne, England|isbn=0-78143-531-5|pages=63}}</ref> Joshua goes on to conquer more cities but never completes the conquest (Joshua 10).<ref name="Paul Wright">{{cite book|last=Wright| first=Paul|title=Joshua, Judges|year=1998|publisher=Broadman & Holman Publishers|location=Nashville, Tennessee|isbn=978-0-8054-9058-9|page=30,31}}</ref>
More kings gather to fight the Israelites. The Israelites defeat and kill them all. Joshua 11 commands the hamstringing of horses.<ref name="Michael Bergman">{{cite book| editor1-last =Bergman | editor1-first= Michael | editor2-last=Murray | editor2-first=Michael J.| editor3-last= Rea | editor3-first= Michael C. |title= Divine Evil?: The Moral Character of the God of Abraham | publisher=Oxford University Press| year= 2011 | isbn=978-0-19-957673-9}}</ref>{{rp|7}}<ref name="Eryl Davies">{{cite book | last=Davies | first = Eryl | title =The Morally Dubious Passages of the Hebrew Bible: An Examination of Some Proposed Solutions | series = Currents in Biblical Research | volume= 3.2 |date = 2005 | pages =197–228}}</ref>
Joshua finishes most of the conquest of Canaan, with the exception of Gibeon and possibly some Canaanites and Amelakites: "For it was of the LORD to harden their hearts, to come against Israel in battle, that they might be utterly destroyed, that they might have no favour, but that they might be destroyed, as the LORD commanded Moses." "And the land had rest from war" (Joshua 11).<ref name="Paul Wright"/>{{rp|68}}
The [[tribe of Manasseh]] is given cities with Canaanites they can´t drive out, but Joshua tells them that they will be able to (Joshua 17).<ref name="Paul Wright"/>{{rp|32}}
In Joshua 20, God tells Joshua to assign [[Cities of Refuge]], so that "the manslayer that killeth any person through error and unawares may flee thither; and they shall be unto you for a refuge from the avenger of blood."<ref name="Paul Wright"/>{{rp|43,44}}
====Book of Judges==== [[File:Tissot Jephthah's Daughter.jpg|thumb|left|Jephthah's Daughter, c. 1896-1902, by James Jacques Joseph Tissot (French, 1836-1902) or follower, gouache on board, 11 5/16 x 7 in. (28.9 x 17.8 cm), at the Jewish Museum, New York]] The [[Book of Judges]] contains a number of violent incidents. There is a graphic description of the assassination of the Moabite King [[Eglon (king)|Eglon]], who [[defecates]] while rolls of his fat suck in the blade used to kill him (Judges 3:22).<ref name="Barry J. Beitzel">{{cite book|last=Beitzel| first=Barry J.| title=Biblica: The Bible Atlas : a Social and Historical Journey Through the Lands of the Bible| year=2007| publisher=Garfield House| location=London, England| isbn=978-1-84537-884-4| page=189}}</ref> Later on, [[Jael]] hammers a tent peg into an enemy commander's head while he slept after fleeing from a battle (Judges 4:21).<ref name="Barry J. Beitzel"/>{{rp|191}} During a time of conflict with [[Ammon]], [[Jephthah]] makes a vow to God that he will sacrifice whatever comes first out of the house and ends up sacrificing his [[Jephthah's daughter|own daughter]] (Judge 11).<ref name="Dallas Theological Seminary">{{cite book|editor1-last=Walvoord| editor1-first=John F.| editor2-last=Zuck| editor2-first=Roy B.| title=The Bible Knowledge Commentary: Old Testament|year=1983|publisher=David C. Cook| location=Colorado Springs, Colorado|isbn=978-0-88207-813-7|pages=400–402}}</ref> Towards the end of the book, an unnamed Levite's concubine is raped, and dies shortly afterwards. The Levite dismembers her, and has parts of her body distributed across Israel to inform people about what happened (Judges 19:29).<ref name="Tokunbo Adeyemo">{{cite book| editor-last=Adeyemo| editor-first= Tokunbo | title=Africa Bible Commentary: A One-Volume Commentary Written by 70 African Scholars| year=2006| publisher=Zondervan| location=Grand Rapids, Michigan| isbn=978-0-310-29187-9| page=315}}</ref> This triggers a civil war between the Benjamites and the Israelites that kills thousands of people.<ref name="Lawrence O. Richards">{{cite book|last=Richards | first=Lawrence O.| title =Bible Reader's Companion|year=1991| publisher=David C. Cook|location=Colorado Springs, Colorado| isbn=978-0-7814-3879-7|page=172}}</ref>
====Books of Samuel==== In the [[Books of Samuel]], The Israelites war with the [[Philistines]] and are defeated at the [[Battle of Aphek]]<ref name="James Maxwell Miller">{{cite book|author1-last=Miller| author1-first=James Maxwell|author2-last=Hayes| author2-first =John H.|title=A History of Ancient Israel and Judah|year=1986| publisher =Westminster John Knox Press| location=Louisville, Kentucky| isbn=0-664-21262-X| page=130}}</ref>. The Philistines [[Philistine captivity of the Ark|capture the Ark of the Covenant]], but God makes his displeasure known, and they later return it<ref name="Robert Alter">{{cite book|last=Alter| first=Robert| title= The David Story: A Translation with Commentary of 1 and 2 Samuel| year=1999| publisher=W.W.Norton and Co.| location =New York| isbn=0-393-32077-4| page=22}}</ref>. The ark arrives at [[Beth-shemesh]], where God slays fifty thousand men for gazing upon it (1 Samuel 6).<ref name="J.Glentworth Butler">{{cite book|title=Joshua, Judges, Ruth, 1st and 2nd Samuel, 1 Chronicles XI., 1 Kings I-XI., 2 Chronicles I-IX|last=Butler|first=J.Glentworth|publisher=Funk and Wagnall's|year=1889|isbn=|location=New York|page=263|pages=}}</ref> [[Samuel]] urges Israel's people to "put away the foreign gods" and serve only God, which they do. The Philistines attack and are defeated at [[Mizpah in Benjamin|Mizpah]].<ref name="J.Glentworth Butler"/>{{rp|291}}
[[Saul]] is made [[Kingdom of Israel (united monarchy)|king of Israel]] and wars with many enemies.<ref name="Diana Vikander Edelman">{{cite book| last= Edelman| first=Diana Vikander| title=King Saul in the Historiography of Judah| year=1991| publisher=Sheffield Academic Press| location=Sheffield, England| isbn=1-85075-321-0| pages=31,32}}</ref> Samuel commands Saul "Now go and smite Amalek, and utterly destroy all that they have, and spare them not; but slay both man and woman, infant and suckling, ox and sheep, camel and ass" (1 Samuel 15:3).<ref name="Diana Vikander Edelman"/>{{rp|99}} Saul does not fully obey, which angers God and Samuel. Samuel kills the captured [[Agag]], king of the Amalekites.<ref name="Diana Vikander Edelman"/>{{rp|107}} [[File:Sweet stories of God; in the language of childhood and the beautiful delineations of sacred art (1899) (14751566596).jpg|thumb|[[David]] raises the head of [[Goliath]]. [[Josephine Pollard]] (1899)]] [[David]], anointed king in secret (1 Samuel 16), comes into Saul's service and "loved him greatly".<ref name="Diana Vikander Edelman"/>{{rp|117-125}} The Philistines attack Israel, David slays their champion [[Goliath]], and they flee. David becomes popular, witch makes Saul fear him and plot his death. David and Saul's daughter [[Michal]] wish to marry, and Saul asks for a dowry of one hundred foreskins of the Philistines. David delivers two hundred, and becomes the king's son-in-law (1 Samuel 18). Saul again wishes David dead, but they are reconciled by Saul's son [[David and Jonathan|Jonathan]].
War comes again, David is victorious. Saul again wants to kill David, and he flees with help from his wife. Saul searches for him and slays the inhabitants of the city [[Nob, Israel|Nob]] for aiding David (1 Samuel 22). David defeats the Philistines at [[Keilah]], then flees the city pursued by Saul (1 Samuel 22). David and Saul reconcile. David seeks refuge with [[Achish]], king of [[Gath (city)|Gath]], and claims he is raiding Judah but is actually raiding and killing in other places (1 Samuel 27). The Philistines begins a war against Saul. David's wives [[Ahinoam]] and [[Abigail]] are taken in a raid on [[Ziklag]], but he rescue them (1 Samuel 30). The men of Israel flee before the Philistines, and three of Saul's sons are slain. Saul asks his armour-bearer to kill him, but is refused, so he takes his own life. The armour-bearer also takes his own life. Saul's body is beheaded and fastened to a city-wall by the victorious Philistines, but it is retaken by inhabitants of [[Jabesh-Gilead]] (1 Samuel 30).
A man tells David of Saul's death and that he himself killed Saul. David has him killed (2 Samuel 1). A long war starts between David and Saul's son [[Ish-bosheth]] (2 Samuel 3). David demands and is granted the return of his first wife Michal, despite the public grief of her new husband [[Palti, son of Laish|Palti]]. Two men assassinate Ish-bosheth, and David has them killed (2 Samuel 4). David wars victoriously with the Philistines. While transporting the Ark of the Covenant to Jerusalem, a man called [[Uzzah]] carelessly touches it and is killed by God (2 Samuel 6).
David defeats and plunder several enemies, and "executed justice and righteousness unto all his people." (2 Samuel 8). [[Ammon#Biblical narrative|The children of Ammon]] mistreat David's emissaries, and is defeated by his army (2 Samuel 10).
In order to make [[Bathsheba]] his wife, David successfully plots the death of [[Uriah the Hittite|her husband]]. This displeases God, and David is told that "the sword shall never depart from thy house." God kills David's and Bathsheba's child, that was conceived during her previous marriage. She then gives birth to [[Solomon]]. David conquers and plunders the city [[Rabbah]] (2 Samuel 11-12).
David's son [[Amnon]] rapes his half-sister [[Tamar (daughter of David)|Tamar]]. [[Absalom]], her full brother, in return has him killed (2 Samuel 13). Absalom conspires and revolts against David. Absalom is finally defeated and dies in the [[Battle of the Wood of Ephraim]], and David mourns him (2 Samuel 15-19). [[Sheba son of Bichri]] revolts, but is ultimately beheaded (2 Samuel 20).
In 2 Samuel 21, David has seven of Sauls sons and grandsons killed, including "the five sons of Michal the daughter of Saul", though he spares Sauls grandson [[Mephibosheth]]. More wars take place. 2 Samuel 23 names and praises several of [[David's Mighty Warriors|David's warriors]].
====The Prophets and Psalms==== Characters like [[Phinehas]] (Num. 25), [[Elijah]] (1 kg. 18:39–40; 2 kg. 1), and [[Elisha]] (2 kg. 2:23–25; 9) killed, ordered killing, participated in killing and foretold killing in the name of God.<ref name=CreachOxford/>{{rp|15}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baylor.edu/ifl/christianreflection/PeaceandWararticleWood.pdf|title=War in the Old Testament|last=Wood|first=John A.|year=2004|work=Center for Christian Ethics at Baylor University|accessdate=4 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://www.baylor.edu/ifl/christianreflection/PeaceandWar.pdf|title=Peace and War|publisher=The Center for Christian Ethics, Baylor University|year=2004|issn=1535-8585}}</ref> Elijah called down fire from Heaven to consume the sacrifice, then followed this display of God's power by catching and personally killing all the prophets of Baal; he twice called the fire down from heaven to consume the Captain and the fifty men with him sent by the King (2 Kings 1:10);<ref name="Friedrich Wilhelm Krummacher">{{cite book| last=Krummacher| first="Friedrich Wilhelm"| title= Elijah the Tishbite| year=1865| publisher=T.Nelson and Sons| location=New York| page=118}}</ref> Elisha called bears from the woods to maul the 42 "youths" who mocked him, and visited leprosy on Gehazi his deceitful servant, (2 Kings 5:27);<ref name="James Murray">{{cite book|last=Murray| first=James| title=The prophet's mantle, scenes from the life of Elisha, son of Shaphat|publisher=William Blackwood and Sons|location=London|pages=34,35,184–189}}</ref> Amos pronounces judgment on the nations including Israel offering a vision of Divine judgment that includes a swarm of locusts and divine fire;<ref name="James L. Mays">{{cite book| last=Mays| first=James L.| title=Amos: A Commentary| year=1969| publisher=The Westminster Press| location=Philadelphia, Penn.|pages=127–131}}</ref><ref name = "John Barton 1980">{{cite book | last = Barton | first = John | title = Amos’s Oracles Against the Nations: A Study of Amos 1:3–2:5 | publisher=Cambridge University Press| location = Cambridge, U.K. | year = 1980}}</ref> Ezekiel said, "The word of the Lord came to me" repeatedly pronouncing violent judgment against the nations and Israel,<ref name="Daniel I. Block"/>{{rp|7,8}}</ref> and a feminist interpretation of the book of Nahum speaks of the "rape" of Ninevah, the book's "fascination with war, and the glee with which it calls for revenge."<ref name="Julia M. O'Brien">{{cite book|last=O'Brien| first=Julia M.| title=Nahum| year=2002| publisher=Sheffield Academic Press Ltd. | location=New York| isbn=1-84127-299-X| page=105}}</ref>
As a response to the violence of the wicked, numerous psalms call on God to bring vengeance on one's personal enemies, for example Ps. 109 calls for vengeance on the entire family as "payment" to the Psalmist's accusers beginning with his children [https://www.biblestudytools.com/lexicons/hebrew/nas/ben.html], including his wife [https://www.biblestudytools.com/lexicons/hebrew/nas/ishshah-2.html] and all his ancestors [https://www.biblestudytools.com/lexicons/hebrew/nas/ab.html].<ref name=CreachOxford/>{{rp|12}} Psalm 137 speaks against Babylon and expresses a desire to dash "their infants against the rocks".<ref name="Erich Zenger">{{cite book | last = Zenger | first = Erich | title = A God of Vengeance? Understanding the Psalms of Divine Wrath| translator= “translated by Linda M. Maloney” | publisher = Westminster John Knox Press | location = Louisville, KY | year = 1994 | pages = 70– 71}}</ref><ref name="Patrick D. Miller Jr.">{{cite book | last=Miller Jr. | first = Patrick D. | title =The Psalter as a Book of Theology in The Way of the Lord: Essays in Old Testament Theology | publisher = Eerdmans | location=Grand Rapids, MI | year = 2004 |pages = 214–225}}</ref>
==In the New Testament== [[File:Brooklyn Museum - The Merchants Chased from the Temple (Les vendeurs chassés du Temple) - James Tissot.jpg|thumb|alt=Jesus holds a whip in his hand in striking position while merchants scramble away, or brace for blows.| A 19th century rendition of the [[Cleansing of the Temple]].]]
===Gospels=== In the [[Gospel of Matthew]], [[Herod the Great]] is described as ordering the [[Massacre of the Innocents|execution of all young male children in the vicinity of Bethlehem]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.catholic.org/encyclopedia/view.php?id=5840|title=Holy Innocents - Encyclopedia Volume - Catholic Encyclopedia - Catholic Online|website=Catholic Online|accessdate=31 October 2017}}</ref>
There are sayings of [[Jesus]] where he states that he comes to bring fire or a [[Not peace, but a sword|sword]].<ref name=Stroumsa>{{cite book|last1=Stroumsa|first1=Gedaliahu G.|editor1-last=Alon|editor1-first=Ilai|editor2-last=Gruenwald|editor2-first=Ithamar|editor3-last=Singer|editor3-first=Itamar|title=Concepts of the other in Near Eastern religions|date=1994|publisher=Brill|location=Leiden u.a.|isbn=9789004102200|pages=173–194|chapter-url=https://www.academia.edu/9111514/Early_Christianity_as_Radical_Religion|chapter=Early Christianity as Radical Religion}}</ref>{{rp|176ff}} The [[cleansing of the Temple]] is a direct violent action by Jesus.<ref name=Addis>''War, A Catholic Dictionary: Containing some Account of the Doctrine, Discipline, Rites, Ceremonies, Councils, and Religious Orders of the Catholic Church'', W. E Addis, T. Arnold, Revised T. B Scannell and P. E Hallett, 15th Edition, Virtue & Co, 1953, Nihil Obstat: Reginaldus Philips, Imprimatur: E. Morrogh Bernard, 2 October 1950, "In the Name of God : Violence and Destruction in the World's Religions", M. Jordan, 2006, p. 40</ref> There are also sayings of Jesus that oppose violence, such as [[Turning the other cheek]] and the passage about [[Jesus and the woman taken in adultery]].<ref name=Stroumsa/><ref name=CreachResources/>{{rp|159}}
The earliest detailed accounts of the death of Jesus are contained in the four [[Biblical canon|canonical]] [[gospel]]s. There are other, more implicit references in the New Testament epistles. In the [[Synoptic Gospel|synoptic]] gospels, [[Jesus predicts his death]] in three separate episodes.<ref>''St Mark's Gospel and the Christian faith'' by Michael Keene 2002 {{ISBN|0-7487-6775-4}} pages 24–25</ref> All four Gospels conclude with an extended narrative of [[Arrest of Jesus|Jesus' arrest]], [[Sanhedrin trial of Jesus|initial trial at the Sandhedrin]] and final trial at [[Pilate's court]], where Jesus is flogged, condemned to death, forced to [[Christ Carrying the Cross|carry his cross]] through Jerusalem, and then [[Crucifixion of Jesus|crucified]], [[Entombment of Christ|buried]], with accounts of [[Resurrection of Jesus|resurrection]] following. His death is described as a [[sacrifice]] in the Gospels and other books of the New Testament.<ref name="David Hawkin">{{cite book | last = Hawkin | first = David J.| title = The twenty-first century confronts its gods: globalization, technology, and war | publisher =SUNY Press | year = 2004 | page = 121}}</ref> In each Gospel these five events in the life of Jesus are treated with more intense detail than any other portion of that Gospel's narrative. Scholars note that the reader receives an almost hour-by-hour account of what is happening.<ref name=Powell>Powell, Mark A. ''Introducing the New Testament''. Baker Academic, 2009. {{ISBN|978-0-8010-2868-7}}</ref>{{rp|p.91}} [[File:Gustave Doré - Christ on the Cross - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|Christ on the Cross. 19th century painting by [[Gustave Doré]]]]
===Apocalypse=== {{Main|Apocalypticism}}
The [[Book of Revelation]] is full of imagery of war, genocide, and destruction. It describes the [[Apocalypse]], the [[Last Judgment#Christianity|last judgment]] of all the nations and people by God, which includes plagues, war, and economic collapse. Some other books of the Gospels also use apocalyptic language and forms. Scholars define this as language that "views the future as a time when divine saving and judging activity will deliver God's people out of the present evil order into a new order...This transformation will be cataclysmic and cosmic."<ref name="James Bailey"/>
Whenever Jesus calls people to a new vision in light of God's impending kingdom, judgment, or a future resurrection, he is using apocalyptic speech.<ref name="James Bailey">{{cite book|author1-last=Bailey| author1-first=James L.|author2-last="Vander Broek"| author2-first=Lyle D.| title=Literary Forms in the New Testament: A Handbook| year =1992|publisher=Westminster/John Knox Press| location=Louiseville, Kentucky|isbn=0-664-25154-4|page=122,123}}</ref> For example, Jesus uses apocalyptic speech in Matthew 10:15 when he says "it will be more bearable for Sodom and Gomorrah on the day of judgment than for that town," and in Mark 14:62, where he alludes to the book of Daniel with himself in the future "sitting at the right hand of God." Bailey and Vander Broek go on to say, "In the material about John the Baptizer there also appear apocalyptic images: 'the wrath to come' (Luke 3:7); 'the axe ... lying at the root of the tree' (Luke 3:9); the Coming One with 'winnowing fork ... in His hand' (Luke 3:17); and chaff burning with 'unquenchable fire' (Luke 3:17)."<ref name="James Bailey"/>{{rp|124}}
Charles B.
